awd_titl_txt: DMREF/GOALI: Discovery and Design of Additives for Novel Polymer Morphology and Performance
awd_abstract_narration:
Plastics like polyethylene and polypropylene constitute an important and increasingly diverse sector of the advanced materials market, due to their unique combinations of processability, mechanical, thermal, optical and even electronic properties. Historically, these materials have been developed and refined over many decades, largely through time-consuming empirical methods.  In today's world, global competitiveness depends on shorter development cycles for the discovery and development of new materials. For example, the design of additives to produce lightweight plastics that are stiffer and tougher than those currently available would benefit societal and economic requirements for energy and material conservation.  With these things in mind, this Designing Materials to Revolutionize and Engineer our Future (DMREF) Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project seeks to accelerate the development of advanced plastics through the rapid evaluation of additives that change the structure, and therefor the properties, of the final product.  It does so through an iterative process of high throughput screening using high performance computing, and targeted experimentation with "best in class" candidates.  This approach represents a new paradigm that can contribute to US competitiveness and innovative practices, which in turn translate into job creation within the US manufacturing economy.  Collaboration with industry on this project provides a mechanism to realize these benefits. This project further serves society through the education and professional development of engineers and scientists, and through propagation of successful practices into other areas of advanced materials discovery. 

The new paradigm for materials discovery envisioned for this project is based on the synergistic application of (i) molecular level simulation, (ii) experimental validation, (iii) materials design and optimization, and (iv) industrial application, to identify essential relationships between molecular structure, morphology and performance.  In the program, this paradigm is realized through the discovery and design of additives (nucleating agents, clarifiers, nanofillers, etc.) that alter the semicrystalline morphology of polyolefins, and thereby their properties as well. Molecular simulations are used to conduct broad screenings of additive classes and then validated experimentally in select cases using a new technique to measure heterogeneous nucleation kinetics.  Evolutionary strategies and related methods are used to design and optimize candidates within and across additive classes, for subsequent synthesis, development and characterization within the laboratories of the industrial collaborator.  This project advances scientific and technical knowledge regarding how the properties and performance of polyolefins can be transformed through rational design of additives that can manipulate crystallization kinetics and semicrystalline morphology.  It results in new theoretical and computational methods that not only predict nucleation kinetics, but also provide insight into nucleation mechanisms.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Global competitiveness in advanced materials depends on shorter development cycles for the discovery and development of new materials.  The objective of this project was a new paradigm for materials research based on the synergistic application of molecular simulation, experiments, and materials optimization and design, to identify essential relationships between molecular structure, morphology and performance.  This paradigm was realized for the discovery and development of additives called "nucleating agents" that allow one to control the crystallization of polyethylene, one of the most ubiquitous polymers in use today.  One major outcome of this project was the demonstration that molecular dynamic simulations can be used to quantify the nucleating agent efficiency of two-component inorganic compounds in the diamond-like and graphene-like material families.  This efficiency was furthermore shown to depend on certain properties of the nucleating agent, specifically its epitaxial match to the polymer crystal lattice, its ability to sustain small strains in order to realize better epitaxial matches, and its interaction strength with the polymer, resulting is useful design heuristics.  A second major outcome was the refinement of the experimental methods to quantify the polymer nucleation rate in the presence of selected additives, especially for the challenging case of fast crystallizing polyethylene.  For the first time, simulations and experiments are shown to agree with respect to relative trends in nucleating agent efficiency, and a new metric called the "thermodynamic efficiency" was introduced that permits meaningful comparison of different polymer-additive combinations.   The third major outcome was the application of a numerical algorithm called Bayesian optimization that identifies promising new additives for experimental examination, thus closing the feedback loop between simulations and experiments.   This algorithm is carefully designed for robustness and reproducibility in the presence of noisy simulation data, which is a challenge that has counterparts in other disciplines (e.g. robotics and process optimization) as well.  With these developments, this project represents a significant step forward for materials discovery in general, and for the design of new additives for polymers that have the potential to modify the semicrystalline polymer morphology and its mechanical, thermal, or optical properties, in particular.

Among its broader impacts, this project strengthens the materials workforce through the research training and professional development of undergraduate students, graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, and through outreach efforts to encourage high school students to consider engineering as a career path.  In collaboration with the Materials Research Society and WebsEdge, a video was produced to increase awareness among peers and society more broadly regarding the Materials Genome Initiative, and NSF's Designing Materials to Revolutionize and Engineer our Future (DMREF) program, in particular.  This video has been viewed over 25,000 times on YouTube alone since December 2018. The advancements made in this project enable the development of advanced materials for the improvement of quality of life and economic development, through the knowledge required to produce lightweight materials with superior properties compared to those currently available, reducing material and energy use, and empowering the individuals necessary to realize these opportunities. 

 


Last Modified: 11/01/2023
Modified by: Gregory C Rutledge

  • Feedback loop between computational exploration of materials space using molecular dynamics simulations, experimental validation in the laboratory, and Bayesian optimization to identify new search spaces.
    Nathan Volchko

por.por_txt_cntn:
Global competitiveness in advanced materials depends on shorter development cycles for the discovery and development of new materials.  The objective of this project was a new paradigm for materials research based on the synergistic application of molecular simulation, experiments, and materials optimization and design, to identify essential relationships between molecular structure, morphology and performance.  This paradigm was realized for the discovery and development of additives called "nucleating agents" that allow one to control the crystallization of polyethylene, one of the most ubiquitous polymers in use today.  One major outcome of this project was the demonstration that molecular dynamic simulations can be used to quantify the nucleating agent efficiency of two-component inorganic compounds in the diamond-like and graphene-like material families.  This efficiency was furthermore shown to depend on certain properties of the nucleating agent, specifically its epitaxial match to the polymer crystal lattice, its ability to sustain small strains in order to realize better epitaxial matches, and its interaction strength with the polymer, resulting is useful design heuristics.  A second major outcome was the refinement of the experimental methods to quantify the polymer nucleation rate in the presence of selected additives, especially for the challenging case of fast crystallizing polyethylene.  For the first time, simulations and experiments are shown to agree with respect to relative trends in nucleating agent efficiency, and a new metric called the "thermodynamic efficiency" was introduced that permits meaningful comparison of different polymer-additive combinations.   The third major outcome was the application of a numerical algorithm called Bayesian optimization that identifies promising new additives for experimental examination, thus closing the feedback loop between simulations and experiments.   This algorithm is carefully designed for robustness and reproducibility in the presence of noisy simulation data, which is a challenge that has counterparts in other disciplines (e.g. robotics and process optimization) as well.  With these developments, this project represents a significant step forward for materials discovery in general, and for the design of new additives for polymers that have the potential to modify the semicrystalline polymer morphology and its mechanical, thermal, or optical properties, in particular.

Among its broader impacts, this project strengthens the materials workforce through the research training and professional development of undergraduate students, graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, and through outreach efforts to encourage high school students to consider engineering as a career path.  In collaboration with the Materials Research Society and WebsEdge, a video was produced to increase awareness among peers and society more broadly regarding the Materials Genome Initiative, and NSF's Designing Materials to Revolutionize and Engineer our Future (DMREF) program, in particular.  This video has been viewed over 25,000 times on YouTube alone since December 2018. The advancements made in this project enable the development of advanced materials for the improvement of quality of life and economic development, through the knowledge required to produce lightweight materials with superior properties compared to those currently available, reducing material and energy use, and empowering the individuals necessary to realize these opportunities.
